senses.de: A formal written request, often signed by many people, asking for something from a government or other authority
senses.ex: They started a petition to stop the new building project.

Tips.title: Social Influence
Tips.description: Petitions often reflect public opinion and seek to persuade authorities by showing widespread support.
Tips.example: The petition garnered thousands of signatures, indicating strong community support.

Tips.title: Formal Request
Tips.description: Petitions are formal; they follow specific formats and sometimes require a minimum number of signatures.
Tips.example: Their petition followed protocol, including a clear statement of purpose and supporting signatures.

Tips.title: Action Motivation
Tips.description: Petitions aim to provoke change or action from authorities, not just to express an opinion.
Tips.example: The petition called for immediate legislative reform.

senses.de: To make a formal written request to a government or other authority
senses.ex: The group petitioned the government to protect the rights of animals.

Tips.title: Seeking Intervention
Tips.description: When petitioning, one usually seeks intervention or action on matters where they lack direct control.
Tips.example: Residents petitioned the city council to improve road safety.

Tips.title: Formal Appeal
Tips.description: The act of petitioning is a respectful and formal appeal, unlike casual requests or demands.
Tips.example: They petitioned the company for clearer communication regarding employee benefits.

senses.de: A request made to God in a religious service
senses.ex: The priest read the petition before the congregation in the church.

Tips.title: Spiritual Request
Tips.description: In religious contexts, a petition is a sincere request reflecting faith, communicated in prayer.
Tips.example: The congregation presented their petitions for peace to the divine in solemn prayer.

Tips.title: Communal Aspect
Tips.description: Religious petitions can be community-centered, shared by many individuals with a common spiritual goal.
Tips.example: During the service, we joined in a communal petition for the sick members of our church.

Appeal.wordDefinition:
Appeal is a legal term that means to request a higher court to review and possibly change a decision by a lower court.

This is used to challenge a court decision that a person or organization disagrees with. For example, if someone is found guilty in a trial, they can appeal to a higher court to review and possibly overturn the verdict.

Appeal is used in legal situations to challenge a decision, while petition is used to ask for action or change from an authority figure or government.

Application.wordDefinition:
An application is a formal request made by someone in order to receive permission, be accepted for a certain position or program, or to get something they need.

For example, if you are applying for a job or a college program, you fill out an application form.

So, while both words involve making a request, applications are used to ask for something you want, while petitions are used to ask for change.

Entreaty.wordDefinition:
Entreaty means to earnestly ask or beg for something. It's usually a personal appeal, that is full of emotion and often addressed to someone in authority.

A good example of this may be a child making an entreaty to his or her parents to allow them to go to a party.

So, in brief, entreaty is for a personal and emotional appeal, while petition is for a formal request for a collective need.

Plea.wordDefinition:
A plea is a request made by an individual for mercy or leniency in a legal case or personal matter. For example, a plea of guilty or not guilty in a court hearing or a plea for forgiveness in a personal conflict.

A petition is used for issues of public concern, while a plea is used for personal matters or legal cases.

Prayer.wordDefinition:
Prayer refers to a spiritual practice of communicating with a deity or higher power.

It is often used in religious contexts as an expression of gratitude or a request for guidance or blessings. For example, a person may offer a prayer before a meal or in times of personal turmoil.

Petition is used to request a specific action from an authority or leader, while prayer is a spiritual practice used to communicate with a higher power.

Request.wordDefinition:
Request is used when a person wants to ask or suggest something to someone else. It could be a casual or formal ask for information, a favor or an action.

But if an individual wants to ask their teacher for extra help after school, they could make a request.

Solicit.wordDefinition:
Solicit means to ask someone for something, usually something like money or support. It's often used by charities or fundraisers who are seeking donations.

For example, a non-profit organization might solicit donations from the public to support their cause.

The main difference between these words is that petition is a formal request for action or change, while solicit is a request for support or donations.

Petition is more often used for change on a societal level, while solicit is more often used for fundraising or asking for support for a specific cause or organization.

Suit.wordDefinition:
A suit is a legal action brought to court to settle a dispute between two parties. The suit can be filed for various reasons such as to seek damages, to terminate a contract, or to challenge a decision made by a government agency.

A petition is a request for a change, while a suit is a legal action taken to resolve a dispute. Petitions are usually non-legal and don't involve a court process, while suits are legal and involve the court system.

Supplication.wordDefinition:
A supplication is a humble request or plea, usually made in a religious or spiritual context. It is a form of prayer that seeks help, guidance or forgiveness from a higher power.

A petition is applicable in situations where a group of people are seeking action or change from a particular authority or organization, while a supplication is more personal and often made in a spiritual or religious setting.
